Basic grammatical relations in Emai show the order Subject-Verb-Object (SVO).
Declarative statements with transitive verbs reveal a subject noun phrase (ólí ómòhè
‘the man’) followed by a verb (é ‘eat’) and its direct object (ólí émàè ‘the food’).
(1) ólí ómòhè é
ólí émàè.
the man PRP.eat the food
‘The man has eaten the food.’
Sentence types contrast with respect to voice-register and tonal pattern. Imperative
constructions utilize a normal voice register.
(2) è ólí émàè.
eat the food
‘Eat the food.’
Declaratives rely on a normal voice register as well.
(3) ólí ómòhè é
ólí émàè.
the man PRP.eat the food
‘The man has eaten the food.’
However, polar interrogatives (yes/no questions), while manifesting the same word
order as declaratives and essentially the same tonal patterns, employ a higher pitch
register.
(4) ólí ómòhè é
ólí émàè?

‘Has the man eaten the food?’
Rhetorical questions are also expressed through this higher register, adding a final
extra-high tone (e.g. é) to a lexical low tone (émàè).

Tonal configurations in Emai reveal the interaction of lexical tone with syntactic
tone values derived from grammatical categories and their placement. Traditional
phrase heads such as nouns and verbs exhibit tonal variability controlled by presence or absence of modifying constituents or of adjacent phrases. For purposes of
illustration, we rely on noun phrases and monotransitive or ditransitive verb
phrases to convey an overview of the nature of this variability, although a full account of principles underlying sentence, clause and phrase tone remains to be undertaken.

7.6.2 Negation ki
Sentence negation (SN) constructions are framed by clause initial ki. They negate an
entire proposition, specifying that it is not shared by speaker and hearer as true. The
construction takes the form of a polar interrogative or a declarative with an obligatory contrary-to-expectation interjection ò. Consequently, ki either queries the proposition expressed in the interrogative with an assumption of doubt or contravenes
the interjection framed declarative structure.

SN subjects admit only one quantifier, collective universal èrèmé. It occurs, although not with the definite article (kí (*élí) éwé èrèmé ó' vbì ìwè ò [SN the goats all
PAP.enter LOC house INT] ‘It surely isn't the case that all the goats entered the

Subject phrases in ki matrix clauses allow most numeral modifiers. One finds
collective ìgbìgbé ‘all ten’ (kí íkpún ìgbìgbé tóó' á vbí ólì èràìn ò? [SN cloths all.ten

LOC house INT] ‘It surely isn't the case that one man entered the house’), and emphatic òkpá ‘alone’ (*kí ólí ómòhè òkpá ó' vbì ìwè ò [SN the man alone PAP.enter LOC
house INT] ‘It surely isn't the case that the man alone entered the house’).
ki subjects accept postnominal modifier phrases. Among the latter are expressions with Associative ísì (kí (ólí) éwé ísì ólí ókpósó ó' vbì ìwè ò [SN the goat ASS the
woman PAP.enter LOC house INT] ‘It surely isn't the case that the woman's goat

PAP.enter LOC house INT] ‘It surely isn't the case that the dark goat entered the

R he PAP.drink the wine PAP.kill the rat INT] ‘It isn't the case that the man who
drank the wine killed the rat, although you may have thought so’). In elicited constructions, there is a preference for definite article inclusion.
Subject position in ki constructions imposes greater restrictions on impersonal
pronouns than personal pronouns. It allows subject pronouns for each person and
number.

Emai complex predicates assert the telic status of a change of existence state. V1
forms denote an incremental change of existence with an implied end state open to718 | Aspect expressing complex predicatestelic specification. Existence end states manifest a distinct perceptual character
when oriented on the vertical or horizontal axis by V2 re and its ‘rise’ or ‘arrive’
sense, respectively. In effect, re expresses a change in entity existence from absence
to presence.
With an intransitive verb, e.g. ze ‘grow,’ or a verb like filo ‘thrust’ as V1, re ‘rise’
predications assume incremental change of state on the vertical axis. They augment
intransitive subject or transitive direct object referent substance and assert perceptible emergence of the referent. In this respect, re predications represent the converse of predications with the postverbal Change of State (CS) a particle. While CS a
predications refer to dissolution of material substance (Chapter 9, 9.3.2.1), re predications refer to emergence of substance. Predications with CS a and re refer less to
change of material state (e.g. from intactness or wholeness toward dissolution) than
to change in entity existence. For re that would be from physically absent to physically present; however, for CS a it would be from physically present to physically
absent. Translation equivalents for re ‘rise’ predications engage English forms of
emergence: prepositions out, up or verbs sprout, arise.

Complex predicates convey a change of positional posture state with intransitive V1
and V2 forms. In simple predicates, V2 forms express a state of posture for the human body. In corresponding complex predications, V2 signals end state of a positional change in posture. V1 and V2 vary in tandem. V1 expresses direction of change
(daa ‘raise,’ dee ‘lower’) and V2 the positional end state (muzan ‘stand,’ mehen ‘lie’).
Component verbs are not only paired but also strictly ordered. V2 muzan follows V1
daa, and V2 mehen follows V1 dee. Predication sense is ‘up’ or ‘down,’ respectively.

Noncanonical constructions in Emai express the information status of a clause or
clause constituent in discourse. Discourse-defined constructions include positive
focus (PF) and negative focus (NF), topicalization, antitopic or right dislocation,
information questions, sentence affirmation (SA) and sentence negation (SN). Each
construction is morphosyntactically marked except topicalization, where intonation
downturn follows the topic constituent. Except for sentence affirmation and sentence negation, each construction is characterized by an additional constituent that
precedes or follows its matrix clause. The resulting discourse position, typically a
noun phrase, corresponds to a matrix clause grammatical relation. Each construction also co-occurs with at least one other construction type, although distinct constructions never affect the same matrix clause constituent.

Focus constructions assume a contrast between speaker and hearer knowledge
regarding the information status of a nominal referent or predicate event. Construc-348 | Noncanonical constructionstion purpose is to align hearer and speaker knowledge. Focus position in this construction expresses information that is not shared by speaker and hearer. Its following matrix clause conveys shared information.
Focus position is marked in affirmative structures by the morpheme li/ni and in
negative structures by ki. Focus position immediately precedes a matrix clause and
its constituent corresponds to a grammatical relation in the matrix clause. For example, the focus position constituent ólí émà followed by li/ni or ki corresponds to
the direct object relation following the matrix verb shen. Focus position noun
phrases manifest an unmarked tone pattern, i.e. they accept a right edge low tone.
On the other hand, focus construction matrix clauses inflect for a limited range of
aspects, all with a right edge high tone subject.

Across affirmative and negative focus types, only positive focus allows omission of
the construction marker. When li/ni is omitted, vowel elision does not affect phonological shape of either focus noun phrase (ólí émà) or matrix clause initial constituent (ólí ómóhé).

Focus constructions show variable grammatical marking of the matrix clause position corresponding to a focus constituent. They also limit nominal structure types in
focus position. As well, they constrain marking of their matrix clause as to inflection, auxiliaries and preverbs.
Focus constructions mark the matrix grammatical relation corresponding to a
focus constitutent with one of three strategies. The first of these affects matrix subject, possessor or first object in a double object complement. Each shows a pronoun
corresponding to the focus position constituent. A positive or negative focus position noun phrase (ólí ómòhè) corresponds to a third person singular pronoun (o ‘he’)
in matrix subject position.

The complementary copula forms vbi and u articulate class membership (CMB).
They assign a referent to a nominal class. Canonical CMB constructions define two
noun phrase positions: the assigned nominal precedes the class nominal with the
copula interposed. The overall syntactic shape of CMB constructions is constrained,
particularly with respect to noun phrase composition and copula verbal properties.

Noncanonical construction co-occurrence | 4137.7 Noncanonical construction co-occurrence
Constructions reflecting sentence affirmation, sentence negation, positive focus,
negative focus, topic, right dislocation and information question types are constrained in their ability to co-occur. For constructions that relate a discourse defined
position to a corresponding grammatical relation, compatibility is possible only
with distinct grammatical relations. No two constructions are compatible when
affecting the same grammatical relation.

Complex predicates consisting of Change of State (CS) particle a or Change of Location (CL) particle o and either of the verbs fi or ku in series express meanings bearing
on object release. They convey change of spatial location that is projected (PCL) orProjected and extended change | 559extended (ECL), change of positional state that is extended (ECPS), change of material state that is extended (ECMS), or state change that is extended (ES). In each, the
subject or direct object referent releases through space, ballistically propelled by
force (PCL) or nonballistically extends through space in a continuous motion (ECL),
extends across a continuous space of change of state (ECPS/ECMS), or extends
across a state (ES). These are summarized in Table 5.

Either it is bounded by an overt
reference point, and thus marked by fi / ku o and a following locative vbi phrase. Or
it is unbounded, and thus not overtly expressed, in which case it is marked by fi / ku
a. Choice of fi or ku reflects grammatical number of affected argument, fi for singular

Bounded and unbounded change predications occur with a variety of verbs in

verbs assume intransitive or transitive shapes where they tend not to accept either

Direct and indirect information questions consist of two constituents: question (or
focus) position and a matrix clause. Interrogative pronouns in question position
correspond to a grammatical relation in the matrix clause.
Matrix clauses across direct and indirect questions limit aspect. They inflect for
Past perfect, Habitual imperfect and Predictive prospective, each of which exhibits a
right edge high tone subject phrase. Question constructions reject Present perfect,
Continuous imperfect and Anticipative prospective, each of which manifests a right
edge low tone subject.

Emai complex predicates identify the telic end state of a change of quantitative
state. Telicity is coded by semantically differentiated V2 forms se, gbe, khoon and so.
Each conveys, respectively, an end state that is sufficient, excessive, satisfactory or
maximal. The entire predication brings into perspective an incremental change of
quantitative state expressed by V1 and assigns to its end state a telic condition.

INDSUBJCONDIQVPDQSpeech & Communication
Informative++++++Conversative+++++-Communicative+++++-Assumptive+-+++-Factuality+-----Perceptive+--+--Desiderative-+----++----KnowledgeEvaluation & Judgment
EvaluativeCo-occurrence constraints between verb and complement type tend to cluster
around verbs of like meaning. For Emai, there appear to be three verb clusters, each
grounded to differences in complement character, as Table 6 indicates. Although all814 | Embedded S- and VP-complementscomplements manifest informational content, this information is differentially interpreted vis-à-vis an event participant variously construed as addressee, affected
experiencer or controlling experiencer. One verb cluster (Speech & Communication)
treats complement content as a message conveyed between speaker and addressee,
not each of whom is syntactically expressed. A second cluster (Knowledge) views
complement content as a human memory state, e.g assumptive, factual, perceptive
or desiderative. And a third cluster (Evaluation & Judgment) considers complement
content for its psychological impact or stimulus effect on an expressed or assumed
affected experiencer.
As Table 6 suggests, complement types are not evenly distributed across the
three verb clusters. Speech and communication verbs accept nearly the full range of
complement types including direct quote, although differences exist according to
subtype. Knowledge verbs are more restricted particularly with respect to subjunctive li and, as might be expected, direct quote. And verbs expressing judgments
evaluating complement content are even more restricted, never taking conditional
si, indirect question, verb phrase or direct quote complements.
Corollary generalizations concern complement types themselves. That is, the
propensity for a complement type to attach to a given verb reflects a hierarchical
tendency imperfectly expressed in the following two schemas. However limited,
these hierarchies represent constraints on complement distribution relative to verbs.
DQ > [khi, li, si]IQ > khiEssentially, no verb takes direct quote without also taking all other complement
types, including subjunctive li and conditional si. The second hierarchy asserts that
no verb takes indirect question without also taking indicative khi.
Another generalization characterizes the combination of complement types
found with any given verb. Although some verbs take only an indicative khi, subjunctive li or conditional si complement (khi/li/si), other verbs take the combination
of indicative, subjunctive and conditional (khi, li, si). Verbs that take more than one
complement do so selectively. Verbs may take indicative khi and subjunctive li. But
no verbs exclusively take khi and si complements or li and si complements. Correlating complement type with semantic verb type provides an initial glimpse into additional properties of embedded complement constructions. Properties associated
with the pairing of semantic verb type and S-, IQ-, VP, and DQ-complement types
are outlined in the following sections.

preverb phrases.

S-complements, IQ-complements and VP-complements vary in their syntactic properties. S-complements headed by indicative khi and conditional si often pattern
alike, while subjunctive li and VP complements often show similar behavior. IQcomplements reveal structural patterns frequently distinct from other complements.
The variable resistance of complement type to grammatical categories reflects a
scale. Indicative khi exhibits the least resistance, with conditional si at nearly the
same level. VP complements show greater resistance along with subjunctive li. IQ
restricts grammatical categories at a level between the pair khi-si and li-VP.1
khi > si > IQ > li >VPEmai’s complement scale is illustrated by polarity and mood expression. Scomplements, IQ-complements and VP-complements show variable polarity and
mood. Sentences incorporating S-complement types, IQ-complements2 and VP complements assume a polar interrogative form uniformly. However, only VP complements assume imperative shape.

Counterfactual condition constructions establish an event that is contrary to fact as
a condition for realizing a second event that has failed to transpire. Emai shows two
types of contrary-to-fact conditions: possible and impossible. The possible type
presents a counterfactual condition potentially reversible in the real world. The
impossible does not entertain reversibility. Subordinate clauses of both types are
framed by kha. Their linked matrix clauses show kha for possible conditions and
Predictive ló for impossible conditions.

Overview of temporal adverbials | 289Morphosyntactically simple temporal adverbs express day units: òdè ‘yesterday,’ éènà ‘today,’ and ákhò ‘tomorrow.’ All correspond to question frame éghè re,
although the day past form, i.e. ákhò ‘tomorrow,’ also shows an í yi question.
Morphosyntactically simple and complex adverbial forms, depending on day
unit, express subintervals semantically grounded to day units. Subinterval adverbs
grounded to moment of utterance refer to immediate present (ènyáà ‘just
now/present’) and immediate past (èghéènà ‘recently’) with morphosyntactically
simple and complex forms, respectively. The corresponding information question
for immediate present is framed by í yi, and for immediate past by éghè re.
Subinterval adverbs grounded to units for past day (ékhèdéà ‘day before yesterday’) and future day (òtíàkhó ‘day after tomorrow’) show complex forms whose
morphological make up remains opaque. Their corresponding information question
frame is éghè re.
Subinterval adverbs within past are morphosyntactically complex forms involving partial or complete reduplication: èdèdé ‘not long ago, a while ago,’ ìghéèghé
‘generations past, long time ago.’ Their corresponding information questions are
framed by éghè re and í yi, with the latter reserved for most distant past: ìghéèghé.
A distal future adverbial grounded to present day is phrasal: ùsúmú éènà ‘nine
days from today.’ Its corresponding information question is éghè re.
Simple deictic adverbs (éénà, ákhò, and òdè) combine with nominal and modifier forms to shape complex adverbial phrases. Day-partitive nominal expressions
combine with day unit forms to denote one of four day divisions: égbìà ‘morning,’
ódìànmì ‘afternoon,’ énwàà ‘evening’ and ásòn ‘night.’ Their corresponding information question frame is éghè re, although those related to òdè ‘yesterday’ also

356 | Noncanonical constructions7.1.3 Matrix clause properties
Focus constructions constrain expression of mood and polarity as well as inflection,
auxiliaries and preverbs. Regarding mood, focus constructions never appear as
imperatives or prohibitives. Relative to polarity, both affirmative and negative focus
constructions appear as polar questions (ólí émà lí / kí ólí ómóhé shén'-ì? [the yam PF
NF the man PAP.sell-F] ‘Was / Wasn’t it the yam that the man sold?’).
In their matrix clauses, affirmative focus constructions allow perfect negation
marked by ì. Negative focus constructions disallow it (ólí émá nà òkpá lí / *kí ólí
ómóhé í ì shèn [the yam this alone PF NF the man SC NEG sell] ‘It was this yam alone
which the man did not sell’).
Matrix clauses in focus constructions limit inflection and auxiliaries. Relative to
aspect, they inflect for Past perfect, imperfect Habitual or prospective Predictive.6
All show a subject phrase with a high tone right edge. Matrix clauses in focus constructions reject Present perfect, imperfect Continuous or prospective Anticipative.
(21) a. ólí émà lí / kí ólí ómóhé shén'-ì.
the yam PF NF the man PAP.sell-F
‘It was / wasn't the yam that the man sold.’
b. émà lí / kí ólí ómóhé ó ò shèn.
yam PF NF the man SC H sell
‘It is / isn't yam that the man sells.’
c. ólí émà lí / kí ólí ómóhé ló
shèn.
the yam PF NF the man PRED sell
‘It is / isn't this yam that the man will sell.’
Focus construction matrix clauses limit deontic and epistemic modality as well
as relative tense. Of the modality forms, deontic Hortative í is never grammatical in
focus constructions. Epistemic forms are not as restricted, even if distributionally
sensitive to focus polarity. Appearing only in negative focus is Certaintive ma (ólí
émà kí / *lí ólí ómóhé má' shèn [the yam NF PF the man PAP.CER sell] ‘It wasn't the
yam that the man surely sold’), while Dubitatives only occur in positive focus polar
interrogative constructions, e.g. bia (ólí émà lí / *kí ólí ómóhé bíá' shèn? [the yam PF
NF the man PAP.DUB sell] ‘Was it the yam that the man actually sold?’) and vba (ólí
émà lí / *kí ólí ómóhé vbá' shèn? [the yam PF NF the man PAP.DUB sell] ‘Was it the
yam that the man really could have sold?’).
Some epistemic forms occur in affirmative and negative focus constructions:
Concessive rere (ólí émà lí / kí ólí ómóhé ré'rè shén? [the yam PF NF the man
PAP.CONC sell] ‘Was / Wasn't it the yam that the man even sold?’) and Hypothetical
kha (ólí émá nà lí / kí ólí ómóhé khà shén [the yam this PF NF the man PAP.HYP sell]
‘It was / wasn't this yam that the man would have sold’). Concessive, though, re-Noun phrase focus | 357quires a polar interrogative structure. Remaining epistemic forms reflecting rational
judgments, Deductive za and Resultative za, fail in focus constructions.
Relative tense exponents appear in focus matrix clauses: Anterior ke (ólí émà lí /
kí ólí ómóhé ké' shèn [the yam PF NF the man PAP.ANT sell] ‘It was / wasn’t the yam
that the man sold afterward’) and Subsequent kpe (ólí émà lí / kí ólí ómóhé kpé' shèn
[the yam PF NF the man PAP.SUB sell] ‘It was /wasn’t the yam that the man sold
despite pending conditions’).
Focus construction matrix clauses severely limit preverb occurrence. For preverbs that occur, there is a tendency to require a nondeclarative, polar interrogative
structure in negative focus constructions.
As a class, aspectualizers interact with focus construction mood and polarity.
Matrix clauses linked to a positive focus position allow aspectualizers Repetitive che
(ólí émà lí ólí ómóhé ché' shèn [the yam PF the man PAP.REP sell] ‘It was the yam
that the man sold again’), Additive gbo (émà lí ólí ómóhé gbó' è [yam PF the man
PAP.ADD eat] ‘It was yam that the man ate too’) and Durative se (émà òkpá lí ólí
ómóhé sé' shèn [yam alone PF the man PAP.DUR sell] ‘It was one yam that the man
still sold’). They reject Punctual ghe, regardless of polarity or mood.
Negative focus matrix clauses accept all phasal aspectualizers but Punctual ghe.
They do so provided the construction assumes a polar interrogative form: che (ólí
émà kí ólí ómóhé ché' shèn? [the yam NF the man PAP.REP sell] ‘Wasn't it the yam
that the man sold again?’), gbo (émà kí ólí ómóhé gbó' è? [yam NF the man PAP.ADD
eat] ‘Wasn't it yam that the man also ate?’) and se (émà òkpá kí ólí ómóhé sé' shèn?
[yam alone NF the man PAP.DUR sell] ‘Wasn't it one yam that the man still sold?’).
Boundary aspectualizers manifest three distribution patterns. Irrespective of
construction polarity or mood, one finds Conative òó (ólí émà lí / kí ólí ómóhé ó ó'
shèn [the yam PF NF the man SC CON sell] ‘It was / wasn’t the yam that the man
went to sell’).
Neither Ingressive ya nor Egressive mo occurs in focus matrix clauses. However,
their Past Absolute functions are available in positive focus: ya (ìmátó nà lí ólí
ómóhé yà dé élá úkpè [car this PF the man PAP.PA buy TP year] ‘It was this car that
the man used to buy in the year we discussed’) and mo (émá mè lí ólí ómóhé mó'
shèn [yam my PF the man PAP.PA sell] ‘It was my yam that the man at one time
sold’). With negative focus, Past Absolutes require a polar interrogative frame: ya
(ìmátó nà kí ólí ómóhé yà dé élá úkpè? [car this NF the man PAP.PA buy TP year]
‘Wasn't it this car that the man used to buy in the year we discussed?’) and mo (émá
mè kí ólí ómóhé mó' shèn? [yam my NF the man PAP.PA sell] ‘Wasn't it my yam that
the man at one time sold?’).
Of the temporal preverbs (kpao ‘initially,’ bobo ‘promptly,’ tua ‘hurriedly’), only
kpao appears in focus matrix clauses (ólí émà lí / kí ólí ómóhé kpá'ò shén [the yam PF
NF the man PAP.earlier sell] ‘It was / wasn't the yam that the man earlier on sold’).

The Specifier copula (SPE) construction identifies a referent for a hearer. It exhibits
a rather rigid syntax. SPE constructions consist of Specifier copula o preceded by a
noun phrase in a focus position that is either overtly marked by negative focus ki or
covertly marked for positive focus. SPE rejects overt marking of positive focus by
li/ni. In its canonical shape, the Specifier copula shows a high low tone.

‘It isn't a thief.’/ óì (*lí) óò.
thief PF be
‘It’s a thief.’SPE constructions show no grammatical subject. Nominative pronouns are not
allowed either in place of initial high tone, as one might expect if the initial high
tone o were the third person nominative pronoun (*ólí ómòhè ó ò [the man he be]430 | Be, do, happen and have‘He is a man’), or in construction with high low tone of copula óò (*ólí ómòhè í / ú óò
[the man I you be] ‘I am / you are the man’).
SPE frames exhibit few grammatical properties typically associated with verb
constructions. óò does not inflect for aspect, at least in the usual Emai fashion. Although the bare SPE copula shows high low tone, it disallows aspect marking as
perfect (neither Past nor Present), imperfect (neither Continuous nor Habitual) or
prospective (neither Predictive nor Anticipative).
Constructions with óò restrict verbal affixes, auxiliaries, preverbs, postverbal
particles and temporal deictic adverbs. Relative to verbal affixes, SPE is incompatible with Perseverative prefix Ci-, Distributive suffix lo/lo/no and Factative suffix -i.
SPE copula tone is uniformly low when preceded by a modal auxiliary. And SPE
is never compatible with a subject pronoun (ó ) preceding an auxiliary.

6.6 Ideophonic adverbs
Ideophonic adverbs articulate meanings that reflect speaker perspective. They need
not express a meaning shared by speaker and hearer and as such are not open to
interrogation by a hearer. Like other adverbs, they occupy postverbal position and
induce high tone spread in an immediately preceding noun phrase constituent.
Ideophonic adverbs assume a variety of morphological shapes and often express meanings typically lexicalized in English verbs. Some exhibit reduplication or
triplication.

A subclass of postverbal adverbs consists of forms whose base morpheme corresponds to a synchronic verb. Deverbalized adverbs exhibit severe syntactic limitations. Among these forms are reduplicated rùrùrúrú and bìbìbíbí. Each corresponds,

2.6.1 Stem reduplication
Stem reduplication exhibits five structural classes. It affects noun, adverbial noun,
pronoun and postdeterminer combinations. The classes vary in their effacement of84 | MorphologyNS-1 final vowel or the portion of NS-2 reduplicated. The resulting reduplicated
forms within the five classes serve primarily as functional rather than lexical items.
For one class of reduplicated forms, the entire stem is repeated. The final vowel
or its tone in NS-1 is thus retained. Members denote relational nouns, temporal adverbials, property nouns, abstract nouns and an item in nature. For some, the semantic effect of reduplication maintains the stem referent while maximally extending a key dimension of referent meaning. For others, reduplication generates a
distinct referent. In one case, the stem referent cannot be synchronically identified.

Reduplication of verb roots occurs in the nominalization of verbs from nouns. A
stem is formed by reduplicating a verb root and adjoining it to a vowel prefix. Vowel
prefix types link with reduplicated roots in no obvious pattern, although half open
vowels [o] and [e] fail to appear in these reduplicated forms. For some lexemes, the
root is still synchronically available; for others, it remains opaque. Members of this
class denote physical entities, insects as well as social and climatic conditions.

Emai exhibits lexical items that reflect contact with various ethnic groups and their
languages in the relatively recent past. As well, some of these lexemes might reflect
a common historical past. For the moment, we do not pursue this historical matter.
Borrowed lexemes derive from English, Yoruba, Hausa and Igbo, among other languages. Most borrowed forms are nouns for concrete or highly abstract objects.
Verbs tend not to be borrowed.
Lexemes that appear borrowed from English denote artifacts, food, locations
and abstractions. Many refer to referents from an English colonial era that persisted
from the 1890s to the 1960s.

Numeral expressions encapsulate within a single semantic domain the range of
Emai morphological types. Analytic compounds, synthetic compounds, derivation
and reduplication are found, as are monomorphemic stem forms. Progressive arithmetic processes of addition and multiplication underlie these lexeme types.
Numbers less than forty are expressed by a root or an analytic compound reflecting addition. Beyond twenty, multiples of twenty are expressed by multiplication, whereas non-multiples of twenty that are still multiples of ten are expressed by
multiplication and addition.
The cardinal numerals for 1-10 are expressed by monomorphemic roots.

Locative ‘be’ (LCT) constructions assign a nominal referent to a location. They are
framed by the complementary predicates ri and e. Each is followed by a prepositional phrase headed by vbi: NP ri vbi NP, NP e vbi NP. Concerning their distribution, ri‘be’ forms | 443appears under realis conditions, e.g. affirmative declarative in the perfect, and e
under irrealis conditions, e.g. imperfect and prospective aspect, negation and deontic modality.
LCT with ri and e differ in polarity and mood potential. e but not ri accepts Perfect Negation. Neither construction displays an imperative or prohibitive shape.

LCT constructions with ri and e show complementary inflection, auxiliaries and
preverbs. Aspect is expressed tonally in an irregular fashion. For Past perfect, ri
shows low tone and right edge high tone subject. For Present perfect, ri shows high
low tone and right edge low tone subject. Under conditions typical for Past and
Present perfect, ri would have shown, respectively, downstepped high (rí') and a
simple high (rí) tone (*ólí ókpósó rí' / ólì òkpòsò rí vbì èkìn [the woman be / the woman be LOC market] ‘The woman was in the market’).

Habitual; neither permits Continuous. Only e permits prospective Predictive; neither
accepts prospective Anticipative.

LCT constructions selectively express deontic and epistemic modality. e accepts
deontic Hortative (ólì òkpòsò í è vbì ìwè [the woman HOR be LOC house] ‘The woman
should be in the house’) and epistemic Hypothetical kha (ólí ókpósó khà é vbì ìwè
[the woman PAP.HYP be LOC house] ‘The woman would have been in the house’). ri
accepts neither.
Locative ri accepts Dubitatives vba (ólí ókpósó vbá' rì vbí ìwè? [the woman
PAP.DUB be LOC house] ‘Could the woman really be in the house?’, ólì òkpòsò vbáà
rì vbí ìwè? [the woman PRP.DUB be LOC house] ‘The woman is not in the house, is
she?’) and bia (ólí ókpósó bíá' rì vbí ìwè? [the woman PAP.DUB be LOC house] ‘Was
the woman actually in the house?’, ólì òkpòsò bíá rì vbí ìwè? [the woman PRP.DUB
be LOC house] ‘Was the woman actually in the house?’), Deductive za (ólì òkpòsò zá
rì vbí ìwè [the woman PRP.DED be LOC house] ‘The woman must be in the house’)
and Certaintive ma (ólí ókpósó má' rì vbí ìwè [the woman PAP.CER be LOC house]
‘The woman surely was in the house’). Neither LCT predicate permits Concessive
rere or Resultative za.
LCT predications restrict relative tense. ri admits Subsequent kpe (ólì òkpòsò kpé
rì / *é vbí ìwè [the woman PRP.SUB be be LOC house] ‘The woman was yet in the
house despite upcoming events’), whereas e permits neither relative tense Subsequent kpe nor Anterior ke.
LCT imposes strong restrictions on preverbs. ri allows aspectualizers Durative se
(ólì òkpòsò séè rì vbí ìwè [the woman PRP.DUR be LOC house] ‘The woman continues to be in the house’) and Past Absolute mo (ólí ókpósó mó' rì vbí ìwè [the woman
PAP.PA be LOC house] ‘The woman at one time was in the house’).
e permits Past Absolute ya but only in polar interrogatives (ólí ókpósó yà é vbí
íwé élá ódíánmì? [the woman PAP.PA be LOC house past afternoon] ‘Did the woman
used to be at home in the afternoons?’). No other aspectualizers are acceptable with
either LCT verb.
LCT constructions reject all remaining preverb classes: evaluative (e.g. kuku),
temporal (e.g. kpao), subject attributive (e.g. dégbe), manner-demonstrative (e.g.
ìyó) and quantity (e.g. dobo óì), as shown in *ólì òkpòsò kúkù / kpáò / dégbè / íyó' /
dóbó óì rì vbí ìwè [the woman PRP.POEV initially steadily DMD REFL her be LOC
house] ‘The woman after all / initially / steadily / that way / by herself is in the
house’.
In LCT constructions verb affixes, postverbal temporal particles and temporal
adjuncts are restricted. Relative to postverbal particles, ri with high low tone admits
Temporal Perspective lee but disallows Temporal Degree gbe (ólí óvbèkhàn ríì vbí‘be’ forms | 445ékín lèé / *gbè [the youth PRP.be LOC market TEMP much] ‘The youth is already in
the market’). Neither particle appears with e.
Each LCT form allows temporal adjuncts consistent with its realis/irrealis character. ri with high low tone accepts ènyáà ‘just now’ (ólí óvbèkhàn ríì vbí ékín ènyáà
[the youth PRP.be LOC market just.now] ‘The youth is in the market right now’),
which otherwise occurs with Continuous and Anticipative, and e allows éènà ‘today’
(ólí óvbékhán ló è vbí ékín éènà [the youth PRED be LOC market today] ‘The youth
will be in the market today’) and ákhò ‘tomorrow’ (ólí óvbékhán ló è vbí ékín ákhò
[the youth PRED be LOC market tomorrow] ‘The youth will be in the market tomorrow’). Neither LCT predicate allows any other deictic adjunct, in particular òdè ‘yesterday’ (*ólí óvbékhán rì vbí ékín òdè [the youth PAP.be LOC market yesterday] ‘The
youth was in the market yesterday’) and èghéènà ‘recently’ (*ólí óvbèkhàn ríì vbí ékín
èghéènà [the youth PRP.be LOC market recently] ‘The youth was in the market recently’).
Neither ri nor e combines with any verb affix, e.g. Perseverative Ci-, Factative -i,
or Distributive -lo/lo/no : *élí íkpósó rì-lò / é-ló' vbì ìwè [the women PAP.be-DS be-DS
LOC house] ‘The women are in the house’.

Complex predicates articulate a relation of source and goal with za ‘move/be located’ and its locative vbi complement as V1 in series. V2 consists of either ye ‘move
toward,’ se ‘move as far as/ reach’ or de re ‘fall to.’ Predication sense is ‘from location X to location Y.’
Source-Goal (SG) predications differentially articulate horizontal and vertical

no expression of manner is conveyed by za in series with ye. za and its complement

Factuality verbs express fact-based information as related to the knowledge state of
their grammatical subject. They include mie ‘find out,’ oo ‘suppose,’ ga ze ‘discover,’
de ‘discover’ and vbohie ‘dream.’ None manifests a ditransitive form. Moreover, mie
and oo are limited to first person subjects. vbohie figures in complex predicates with
mie to modulate situational aspect of complement content. Factuality verbs are
limited to khi marked S-complements. They reject those marked by li, si or IQ. Further, factuality verbs limit aspect to the perfect and, except for polar interrogatives,
tend to restrict polarity and mood expression. Complement types with factuality
verbs are embedded as direct objects. None but that of mie corresponds to an interrogative pronoun and none corresponds to manner demonstrative pronoun ìyó ‘so.’
Overwhelmingly, factuality verbs constrain subject identity across complement and
matrix clauses by rejecting logophoric pronouns. Additional properties emerge from
consideration of each verb and its S-complements.

Cultural and Linguistic Background
Emai is mother tongue for approximately 25,000–35,000 members of the Emai clan
in south central Nigeria. It is spoken in ten villages across roughly 250 square kilometers on the plateau between the Edion and Owan rivers of present-day Edo State.
Located at longitude 6° east of Greenwich Meridian and latitude 7° north of the
equator, this area consists primarily of tree savanna, allowing for bush agriculture
involving the harvesting of yam, maize, cassava, and beans among other crops
(Bradbury 1957). Serving as the principal political village of the Emai is Afuze. Other
villages in the clan are Eteye, Evbiame-New-Site, Evbiame-Old-Site, Ogute, OjavunNew-Site, Ojavun-Old-Site, Okpokhunmi, Ovbionwu, and Uanhumi.
The Emai-speaking region is approximately 120 kilometers north of Benin City
by road. It is connected in the south to Sabongida, the principal village of the related Ora clan, in the east to Uzebba, the primary village of the related Iuleha clan, and
in the north to Auchi, the headquarters of the Edoid language Yekhee.
As for the Emai people, oral tradition makes clear the absence of hereditary
chieftancy, a cultural feature frequent among Edoid peoples of its region. According
to oral tradition (Ogbomo 1994), the ancestor of the Emai people is Ima. He is said to
have fled from the ancient kingdom of Benin in about the 16th Century for committing murder. Ima and his wife, who also came from Benin, had a son Uzuanbi (Oyaibi). Uzuanbi, in turn, had two wives, Odidi and Oron, whose sons founded the Emai
speaking villages. Oral tradition varies at this point. According to one version, the
four sons of Uzuanbi and his wives were Uwuno, Urule, Ivbiame, and Uanhumi,
each of whom founded a village. Their sons, Uzuanbi's grandsons, founded the ten
quarters into which the four villages became divided. According to another version,
the village of Uanhumi is named after the son of one wife and the remaining villages
are related to three sons of a second wife. The sons were Uule, Evbiame and
Ovbionwu, whose names are retained, respectively, by the village sites of Ugbuule,
Evbiame-Old-Site, and Ovbionwu, all of which are located off the main Ora-Auchi
road and tend to be northernmost in their respective village groups. Each of these
villages serves to link the remaining Emai-speaking area. Villages in the Uule group,
from south to north, are: Ojavun-Old-Site, Okpokhumi, Eteye, Uanhumi, Afuze,
Ojavun-New-Site. Ugbuule no longer exists as an occupied village. The Evbiame
group from south to north consists of Evbiame-New-Site, Ogute, and Evbiame-OldSite. The Ovbionwu group consists solely of Ovbionwu.
As a linguistic entity, Emai is completely surrounded by Edoid speech varieties.
Its genetic classification as a distinct linguistic unit within Edoid is of recent origin.
Elugbe (1973) classified it as part of a dialect cluster incorporating adjacent OraPreface | ix(30,000 speakers) and Iuleha (45,000 speakers); Elugbe (1989) locates this cluster
more specifically within the North Central Branch of Edoid. While a word list supporting a cluster relationship among these dialects was not published, broader classificatory schemes have accepted the cluster interpretation, e.g. Hansford, BendorSamuel and Stanford (1976), Bendor-Samuel (1989) and Crozier and Blench (1992).
Even Christian missionary activity in the area has never generated word lists, since
neither the Bible nor a church hymnal is available in Emai.
Linguistic investigation of individual languages within the Edoid group is extremely limited. Other than Emai, no descriptive grammatical treatment, encompassing reference grammar, lexicon, and texts, has appeared for a single member of
the 25 or more Edoid languages. Perhaps the most widely recognized comparative
and historical analysis of the Edoid group is Elugbe's (1973) unpublished dissertation “A Comparative Edo Phonology” and its successor, Comparative Edoid: Phonology and Lexicon (Elugbe 1989). Also showing an exclusive interest in phonological
matters is Elimelech's (1979) A Tonal Grammar of Etsako, which examines the role of
pitch differences in words and short phrases among dialects of Yekhee spoken
northeast of Emai country.
Among other Edoid studies, Thomas (1910) presents a highly schematic grammatical and lexical analysis of Bini, the numerically and culturally dominant language of the group since establishment of the influential Edo Kingdom in the 13th
Century (Ryder 1969). Later studies of Bini amplify portions of this initial analysis.
Melzian (1937) is a descriptive dictionary from which one can infer grammatical
information at the level of parts of speech, while Amayo (1976) and Wescott (1962)
offer accounts of Bini phonology and morphology. Several linguistic studies of Bini
in pedagogical or descriptive formats have followed. Dunn's (1968) An Introduction
to Bini is a training manual prepared for the American Peace Corps and as such
couches most of its language material in a limited variety of dialogue formats for the
prospective volunteer. An additional pedagogically oriented study is An Edo-English
Dictionary by Agheyisi (1986), which is intended for use in primary and secondary
schools. Stewart (1998) provides a theoretical interpretation of selected serial verb
constructions in Bini.
Additional linguistic studies of Edoid speech varieties tend to be descriptive.
Ejele (1986) provides an overview of selected syntactic issues in Esan. Kari (1997)
provides a brief grammatical sketch of the Delta Edoid language Degema, which is
followed by a more detailed and illustrated descriptive grammar (2004).
As for Emai, an initial lexicon and orthographic statement is offered by Schaefer
(1987), while Egbokhare (1990) presents an initial phonological analysis. An extensive collection of Emai oral tradition texts is found in Oral Tradition Narratives of the
Emai People, Parts I and II (Schaefer and Egbokhare 1999b). This is complemented
more recently by A Dictionary of Emai: An Edoid Language of Nigeria (Schaefer and
Egbokhare 2007). Additional information on Emai is available in a number of papersx | Prefaceby Schaefer and Egbokhare published in a variety of books and journal articles. Of
particular relevance to the future of Emai as a spoken medium is Schaefer and Egbokhare (1999a), which found an intergenerational shift to English as home language in the mid-1990s without a commensurate negative evaluation of vernacular
mother tongue.

3.2.2 Evaluative preverbs duu, woo, kuku
Evaluative preverbs reflect speaker attitude toward event occurrence. They consist
of Evaluative (EVAL) duu ‘in fact but for no discernable reason,’ Preferential Evaluative (PREV) woo ‘instead,’ and Post-Evaluative (POEV) kuku ‘afterall.’ No evaluative
preverb answers a direct question. Relative to one another, evaluative forms fail to
combine in a preverbal phrase.

gbé ólí ófè.
the man PRP.EVAL kill the rat
‘The man killed the rat for no reason.’
b. ólí ómòhè ò ó wóó è ólí émàè.
the man SC C PREV eat the food
‘The man is eating the food instead.’
c. ólí ómòhè kúkù
é ólí émàè léé.
the man PRP.POEV eat the food TEMP
‘The man finished eating the food after all.’
Evaluative preverbs evince distinct constraints regarding inflection, modality
and relative tense. Each exhibits distinct inflection. Evaluative duu appears in Past
and Present perfect or Predictive and Anticipative but not Continuous and Habitual:
(ólí ómóhé dú'ú gbé ófè [the man PAP.EVAL kill rat] ‘The man killed a rat for no reason’), (ólí ómòhè dúù gbé ólí ófè [the man PRP.EVAL kill the rat] ‘The man has killed
the rat for no reason’), (ólí ómóhé ló dùù é ólí émàè [the man PRED EVAL eat the
food] ‘The man will eat the food for no reason’), and (ólí ómòhè ló dùù é ólí émàè [the
man ANTI EVAL eat the food] ‘The man is about to eat the food for no reason’).

In age constructions, the forms u and vbi occur in complementary distribution or
